levels.label: Ready
levels.message: You selected ERP/CBT principles and appropriate pharmacotherapy sequencing—classic EPPP targets.

levels.label: Close
levels.message: You’re close—review the strongest evidence base for OCD and what to do when response is partial.

levels.label: Review Needed
levels.message: OCD treatment is highly testable. Review ERP and SSRI strategies vs. non–first-line options.

nodes.prompt: A 28-year-old reports intrusive contamination obsessions and spends 3–4 hours/day washing and cleaning. Symptoms have caused work impairment. There is no current substance use and no psychosis. What is the BEST first-line treatment approach?

options.text: Supportive therapy focused on insight and emotional expression, without behavioral exposure.
options.rationale: Supportive approaches can help engagement, but the most evidence-based first-line psychotherapy for OCD is exposure and response prevention (ERP), typically within CBT.

options.text: Exposure and response prevention (ERP) and/or CBT, with consideration of an SSRI if symptoms are moderate-to-severe or if psychotherapy alone is insufficient.
options.rationale: ERP is a core first-line treatment for OCD. SSRIs are also first-line medications; combined treatment may be indicated with higher severity or functional impairment.

options.text: Benzodiazepine monotherapy to reduce anxiety, continued long-term.
options.rationale: Benzodiazepines are not first-line for OCD and carry risks with long-term use; they do not target the obsessions/compulsions as effectively as ERP/SSRIs.

options.text: Antipsychotic monotherapy as the primary treatment because compulsions indicate severe pathology.
options.rationale: Antipsychotics are not first-line monotherapy for OCD; they may be used as augmentation in select partial responders to SSRIs, not as initial standalone treatment.

nodes.prompt: After an adequate ERP trial plus an SSRI at a therapeutic dose for several weeks, the patient has only partial improvement. What is a reasonable next step?

options.text: Stop ERP because exposure increases distress and replace it with reassurance and avoidance strategies.
options.rationale: Avoidance and reassurance can reinforce OCD cycles. ERP discomfort is expected; optimizing ERP is often part of effective care.

options.text: Optimize evidence-based care: ensure ERP is delivered with sufficient intensity and consider medication adjustments (e.g., SSRI optimization/switch) or augmentation when indicated.
options.rationale: EPPP-style items reward “optimize first-line treatment” before moving to non-evidence-based options. For partial responders, intensifying ERP and adjusting SSRI strategy are common next steps.

options.text: Switch immediately to long-term benzodiazepines because they reduce anxiety faster than SSRIs.
options.rationale: Speed of symptom relief is not the main criterion. Benzodiazepines are not a core OCD treatment and do not directly reduce obsessions/compulsions.

options.text: Recommend stopping all medication and using only relaxation training because it is less activating.
options.rationale: Relaxation can help general stress but is not sufficient as a primary OCD intervention in a patient with significant functional impairment.

nodes.summary: First-line OCD treatment is ERP (often within CBT) and/or SSRIs. If response is partial, optimize ERP delivery and medication strategy before pivoting away from evidence-based care.
takeaways: ERP is the hallmark psychotherapy for OCD.
SSRIs are first-line pharmacotherapy; combined care can be appropriate with higher severity.
Partial response: optimize ERP intensity and adjust SSRI strategy; augmentation may be considered in select cases.

nodes.summary: You aimed to reduce distress quickly, but OCD outcomes are best when you optimize ERP/SSRI strategies rather than relying on anxiolytic-only approaches.
takeaways: OCD treatment targets obsessions/compulsions, not just distress.
ERP discomfort is expected and can be therapeutic.
If response is partial, adjust the evidence-based plan rather than abandoning it.

nodes.summary: This scenario is a classic EPPP treatment item: ERP/CBT and SSRIs are core first-line treatments for OCD. Review the evidence base and next-step planning for partial response.
takeaways: ERP is a first-line psychotherapy for OCD.
SSRIs are a first-line medication class for OCD.
